title: RL32541
content: The 9/11 Commission found that al Qaeda terrorists exploited weaknesses in aviation security, including a pre-screening process focused on bombers, lax checkpoint screening, lack of in-flight security measures, compliance with hijackers, and a lack of protocols for the FAA. The 9/11 Commission identified a lack of protocols and capabilities for coordinated responses to hijackings and suicidal hijackers, attributing it to a failure of imagination among senior policymakers and agencies responsible for intelligence, defense, and aviation security. Aviation security experts were slow to consider suicide hijackings as a threat despite concerns from some agencies. Prior to September 11, 2001, aviation security experts underestimated the likelihood of a suicide hijacking scenario, and there were no specific actions taken to defend against this threat. Congressional oversight of aviation security was lacking, with a focus on airport congestion and passenger service instead. After the September 11, 2001 attacks, Congress swiftly passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) to address aviation security weaknesses. ATSA established the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security in all modes of transportation. The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) established the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security in all modes of transportation. ATSA included measures such as federal security screeners at airports, explosive detection screening for checked bags, air marshals on high-risk flights, and cockpit door hardening. It also granted TSA broad authority to assess and address security threats in all transportation modes, with a focus on aviation security. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 established the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and placed the TSA within it. The act also allowed arming of airline pilots for security. The Vision 100 Act included measures like an aviation security capital fund for explosive detection systems in baggage conveyers. The TSA has implemented measures to improve baggage screening efficiency and arm pilots, but vulnerabilities in air cargo operations, general aviation, employee access controls, screener performance, and potential terrorist attacks with shoulder-fired missiles persist. The 9/11 Commission also identified these security gaps, emphasizing the need for improvements in cargo and general aviation security. The 9/11 Commission made recommendations for airport passenger and baggage screening, and air cargo security, but did not address concerns about access controls in airports and general aviation operations or shoulder-fired missile attacks on commercial airliners. The 9/11 Commission recommended a multi-layered security system for aviation security, emphasizing the need for effective coordination and redundancies to address possible terrorist tactics. The 9/11 Commission recommended a multi-layered security system for aviation security, emphasizing coordination and redundancies to address possible lapses. This aligns with aviation security mandates and TSA's "concentric rings of security." The Commission focused on persisting vulnerabilities in commercial aviation and made six aviation-specific recommendations, including enhancing passenger pre-screening and improving explosives detection on passengers. The 9/11 Commission issued six aviation-specific recommendations to enhance security, including improving explosives detection on passengers and deploying hardened cargo containers on passenger aircraft. Additionally, an overarching recommendation was made for transportation security policy to prioritize based on risk and implement cost-effective deterrents. On September 11, 2001, passenger pre-screening consisted of three measures. On September 11, 2001, passenger pre-screening measures included CAPPS, security questions, and photo ID. Over half of the hijackers were identified, but with little consequence as pre-screening was focused on preventing bombings like Pan Am flight 103. The CAPPS system is still in use today. The CAPPS system, used for passenger pre-screening, has expanded to screen for possible hijackers. CAPPS II, the follow-on system, has faced controversy over data protection and civil liberties concerns. It would authenticate passenger identity using commercial databases and check names against terrorist profiles. The 9/11 Commission recommended improving passenger pre-screening by utilizing federal watchlists and not delaying implementation. Legislation directed the Department of Homeland Security to address concerns and limited CAPPS II implementation to system testing until verified by the Government Accountability Office. Airlines' reluctance to provide data for testing due to liability concerns has hindered progress. Recent reports suggest challenges in the implementation of the CAPPS II program. The CAPPS II program has been scrapped over privacy concerns, but a new program may take its place. Congress may increase oversight of the Secure Flight program and debate the best way to proceed. H.R. 10 includes a provision for TSA to take over passenger pre-screening from airlines within 180 days. The TSA is required to take over responsibility for prescreening from airlines within 180 days of enactment and start testing the system by November 1, 2004. The 9/11 Commission highlighted evidence of al Qaeda's interest in bombing airliners, referencing Ramzi Yousef's 1994 bombing of a Philippines Airlines flight as a precursor to a larger operation. The 9/11 Commission highlighted concerns over improvised explosive devices (IEDs) in airline security, referencing incidents involving Ramzi Yousef, Richard Reid, and Nathaniel Heatwole. Persistent weaknesses in detecting IEDs were acknowledged. The 9/11 Commission recommended improving explosives detection on passengers, suggesting all individuals selected for secondary screening undergo explosives screening due to limited capabilities of current screening technologies. New technology can detect bomb-making chemicals. New technology is being tested at various airports to detect bomb-making chemicals on individuals using trace detection methods. Other methods include body scan imaging using low dose x-ray backscatter, which is controversial due to the nude images it produces. The 9/11 Commission recommended implementing more effective passenger screening methods, which may include body scan imaging technology. This technology is controversial due to privacy concerns. Congress may debate funding for these initiatives. The TSA has launched initiatives to address screener performance issues highlighted by a recent DHS Inspector General's audit. These initiatives include expanding the use of threat image projection (TIP) to test screener performance and improve human performance needs in aviation security. The TSA is working on improving recurrent training for screeners and addressing key human factors issues in aviation security, such as screener selection, training, and interaction with screening technologies. However, research and funding for human factors in aviation security are lacking compared to other agencies like the Department of Defense and FAA. There is a lack of a comprehensive strategic plan for addressing human factors in aviation security. Congress may conduct oversight to identify areas where TSA's human factors research efforts may not be addressing concerns over passenger and baggage screening performance. Congress may also consider tasking an independent body with examining human factors needs in aviation security. The National Academy of Sciences addressed human factors in a 1999 assessment of aviation security technologies but has not conducted a focused study on human factors needs in aviation security. H.R. 10 includes a provision for TSA to conduct human factors studies to improve screener performance and evaluate next-generation checkpoint screening technologies. The 9/11 Commission recommended that the aviation industry should contribute to the costs of in-line EDS deployment, which has been a point of contention. The 9/11 Commission recommended intensifying efforts to identify and screen suspicious cargo in aviation and maritime operations. The TSA unveiled a strategic plan for cargo security in aviation and maritime operations in November 2003, based on recommendations from the Aviation Security Advisory Committee. The plan includes a multi-layered risk-based approach with four key strategic objectives: enhancing shipper and supply chain security, pre-screening elevated risk cargo, using technology for targeted air cargo inspections, and securing all-cargo aircraft through facility security measures. The goals of the plan involve pre-screening all cargo shipments to determine their relative risk levels. The TSA's strategic plan for cargo security includes pre-screening all shipments to determine risk levels, inspecting items of elevated risk, deploying new technology solutions, and implementing security programs. The 9/11 Commission supports the overall approach but calls for accelerated progress and possibly additional measures. TSA's risk-based approach relies on the known-shipper program and database for assessing shipments. The 9/11 Commission recommends enhancing cargo security by improving screening and tracking measures. A proposal suggests deploying hardened cargo containers on passenger aircraft, estimated to cost $125 million. Industry-wide cost of lost revenue due to reduced payload and increased fuel burn is estimated at $11 million annually. Opposition may arise from airlines due to increased operational costs, with arguments that improved cargo identification, tracking, and screening may negate the need for hardened containers. Proponents argue that deploying hardened cargo containers on passenger aircraft adds a redundant layer of defense. However, using just one container still leaves the system vulnerable to risks tied to cargo assessments. TSA requires proper vetting for all cargo to mitigate potential vulnerabilities. The TSA is working on expanding capabilities to detect high-risk cargo for all-cargo airplanes, but it is unclear how this system could be adapted for passenger airplanes. Congress may debate whether deploying hardened cargo containers on passenger aircraft could provide an effective layer of security. The debate revolves around whether deploying blast-resistant cargo containers on passenger aircraft could enhance security. H.R. 10 includes a provision for a pilot program to assess the use of these containers, while S. 2845 does not. Additionally, legislation passed by the Senate requires a report on blast-resistant cargo container technology. The 9/11 Commission recommended a risk-based approach for aviation security, involving federal, state, and local authorities, as well as private stakeholders. While the TSA initially focused on meeting ATSA mandates post-9/11, there is a need for a unified strategic plan for national aviation security policy. The TSA is poised to develop a formal strategy for national aviation security policy, likely based on a risk-based multi-layered approach. Congress may task the TSA with creating a national strategy that addresses funding, roles of authorities, and industry stakeholders. The need for a formal strategic planning document for aviation security is highlighted, emphasizing the importance of cooperation and integration among various stakeholders. Challenges persist in defining roles and allocating resources for state, local, and industry involvement in airport security programs. The role of local jurisdictions and airport operators involves security oversight, while TSA is responsible for passenger screening. Local governments and state authorities support aviation security through law enforcement presence at screening checkpoints. Passenger air carriers participate in security through procedures and training for controlling access to aircraft and secured areas. Security measures in air cargo and general aviation rely on direct participation. In air cargo and general aviation, security measures rely on direct participation of aircraft owners and operators, with federal oversight and enforcement. However, there is a lack of unified plan for assigning roles and missions to stakeholders and adopting a systems approach for overall security strategy. Congress and the TSA may consider improving strategic planning, resource allocation, and integration of resources for aviation security, including aligning aviation security strategies with a broader transportation security strategy. The 9/11 Commission report prompted Congress to focus on aviation security recommendations. The 108th Congress passed two major pieces of legislation related to transportation security. The 108th Congress passed legislation related to aviation security, including Vision 100 and the National Intelligence Reform Act in response to the 9/11 Commission's recommendations.
